author: Vlad Litnarovych
title: Russia's Troop Losses in Ukraine Now Hit 1 Million, General Staff Says
text:
- Category
Latest news
Russiaâ€™s Troop Losses in Ukraine Now Hit 1 Million, General Staff Says
Russiaâ€™s total military losses in Ukraine have surpassed 1,000,000 personnel, including those killed, wounded, or incapacitated, according to a June 12 report by Ukraineâ€™s General Staff.
On June 11 alone, Russian forces sustained an additional 1,140 casualties, the General Staff added, along with dozens of units of military equipment destroyed.
â€œThe overall losses of the Russian occupying forces in manpower since the beginning of the full-scale invasion have reached one million,â€ the General Staff stated. â€œMore than 628,000 occurred in just the past year and a half.â€
Breakdown of Russian casualties by year:
2022: 106,720 troops lost â€” averaging 340 per day
2023: 253,290 troops â€” averaging 693 per day
2024: 430,790 troops â€” averaging 1,177 per day
2025 (as of June 4): Over 200,000 troops â€” averaging 1,286 per day
Ukraine first began publicly tracking and publishing Russian losses on March 1, 2022, when the count stood at 5,710 killed and 200 captured. The next day, losses rose to 5,840, and by March 3, the figure was revised upward to 9,000 after verification.
Some of the heaviest days of Russian losses occurred on:
November 28, 2024: 2,030 casualties in a single day
December 19, 2024: 2,200 casualties
December 29, 2024: 2,010 casualties
The Ukrainian military emphasized that the one-million mark is not just a statistic but a symbol of resistance and resilience.
â€œOne million. Thatâ€™s how much the enemyâ€™s offensive potential has diminished,â€ the General Staff wrote. â€œOne million who could have destroyed us, but whom we destroyed instead.â€
The statement went on to highlight the symbolic meaning behind this figure, referencing sites of mass Russian losses and Ukrainian sufferingâ€”from the Red Forest near Chornobyl and the Dnipro River near the Antonivsky Bridge, to the hills of Donbas, the fields of Kharkiv region, and the depths of the Black Sea, where the cruiser Moskva lies.
â€œThis is our answer for Bucha, Irpin, Kupiansk, Kherson,â€ the statement continued. â€œFor the maternity hospital in Mariupol, for the Ohmatdyt childrenâ€™s hospital destroyed in Kyiv. For the tears of our children, the civilians shot dead, the homes turned to rubble.â€
Ukraine also expressed gratitude to every soldier, sailor, sergeant, officer, and general who contributed to the fight, reaffirming that â€œevery eliminated occupier is another step toward a just peace.â€
â€œToday, weâ€™ve taken more than a million such steps,â€ the General Staff Concluded.
Earlier, NATO officials on April 3 confirmed that Russia suffered over 250,000 military deaths since launching its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, with total lossesâ€”killed, wounded, or incapacitatedâ€” surpassing 900,000.

author: Cathalena E. Burch
title: U of A Opera's 'Thumbprint' sends message for Tucson women
text:
In perhaps one of the most devastating scenes of the University of Arizona Opera Theatre â€˜s performance Wednesday of â€œThumbprint,â€ it is what we didnâ€™t see on stage that struck the deepest emotional blow.
But we knew what was happening.
We could sense it as the mood shifted in Kamala Sankaramâ€™s wonderful tapestry of Indian raga and Western music performed by a six-member ensemble under the baton of guest conductor Kristin Roach. The rich Indian accents went from playful when Mukhtar Mai (soprano Aysen Milliogullari) and her mom (soprano Beth Jargstorf) teased little sister Annu (alto Betsey Carter) to ominous when the group of tribesmen came seeking retribution. The striking bell-like tones from the tabla stabbed the air like a knife and repeated ragas set to Western harmonies drove the drama until it became near quiet and all we heard was what sounded like a woman gasping for air.
People are also readingâ€¦ Aldi is opening its first Tucson grocery store Hobbs vetoes bills on school showers, residency for voting, squatters, more New retail development coming to Marana Tim Steller's column: Tucson's biggest homeless camp faces upcoming clear-out More Arizona stores to be sold in latest Kroger, Albertsons merger plan 95-year-old Tucson high-rise building to be sold at auction New policy could eliminate hundreds of Pima County government jobs Group launches campaign to oust 2 Arizona justices over abortion ruling Ranking the craziest foods at this year's Pima County Fair ðŸ¨ 50 fun events happening in Tucson this weekend April 25-28 ðŸŽ ðŸŽ¨ Councilwoman threatens to picket home of 'notorious South Tucson slumlord' Winning $12 million lottery ticket sold in Marana See what's being cut: U of A releases preliminary budgets for colleges As The Hungry Fox turns 60, the owners plan to open a second location ðŸ³ðŸ¥ž This local food truck is bringing a taste of Oaxaca to Tucson We also heard it in Mukhtarâ€™s cries that she wouldnâ€™t follow tradition and lock herself up in her room or, worse, kill herself to redeem the shame the attack left on her family. And we heard it in the denials of her chief attacker Faiz (tenor Jess Barrera), who hid behind the cloak of â€œhonorâ€ and â€œtradition,â€ words that flashed on the screens in Sally Dayâ€™s dramatic set design.
The UA Opera Theatre, under director Cynthia Stokes, could have closed the 2023-24 season with a warhorse from the Western operatic cannon, maybe a frolic with Mozart and or the bold romance of Bernsteinâ€™s â€œWest Side Story.â€
But thereâ€™s one thing weâ€™ve learned since Stokes took over the opera program in 2016: She hasnâ€™t met an artistic challenge sheâ€™s not willing to tackle.
Listen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack
Stokes introduced herself to Tucson in 2017 with Benjamin Brittenâ€™s â€œ The Rape of Lucretiaâ€ at a time when the headlines were filled with tales of powerful celebrities being accused of sexually-related crimes at the height of the #MeToo movement.
But â€œThumbprintâ€ resonates even deeper. Stokes showed us a culture that we have only witnessed from afar, glances on the evening news when tensions in the Middle East rise. But at its core, the message of â€œThumbprintâ€ is universal; itâ€™s about empowering women and the disenfranchised. Itâ€™s a message that we sorely need today with womenâ€™s reproductive rights and health care under attack nationwide and economic and social justice disparities growing.
If you go to see â€œThumbprintâ€ and you walk away feeling energized to make a change in your world, consider the message delivered.
But the other reason youâ€™ll want to see this is to hear the amazing coloratura soprano range from Milliogullari and Jargstorf, who were the dominant voices throughout the 90-minute performance, and to see the brilliant tenor Barrera play such a wretchedly awful character so believably that you had to remind yourself he was just acting.
Other standout performances included bass Zhixiang â€œLukeâ€ Xie as Mukhtarâ€™s father and the orchestra under Roach, who brought out the rich cultural intersection of Sankaramâ€™s Hindustani and Western European score.
UA Opera Theatre will perform â€œThumbprintâ€ at 7:30 p.m. Thursday, April 18, and Friday, April 19, and 3 p.m. Saturday, April 20, at Crowder Hall, 1017 N. Olive Road, in the UA School of Music. Get tickets ($10-$20) at am.ticketmaster.com/uacfa/buy/music .
Reproductive rights and policies regarding health care for childbearing have a significant impact on the economic future of both individuals and communities.The Economic Policy Institute found that states where abortion bans take hold have historically had "intentionally constructed" economic policies with weak labor laws in underfunded areas with dysfunctional public services. Sara Estep, an associate director with the Women's Initiative at the Center for American Progress, said the Congressional Budget Committee's hearing this week on the economic impacts of reproductive rights is "a huge deal.""It's really important that we talk about this issue as an economic issue," Estep said. "Whenever women are forced to have children that they may not have wanted to have, it has profound economic effects on their lifespan."SEE MORE: Families impacted by Alabama IVF ruling head to state capitolThis week, Republican Sen. Chuck Grassley of Iowa said, "Abortion, above all, is a moral and legal issue. Abortion is not an issue that lends itself to being looked at solely through an economic lens. After all, life is priceless."For proponents of female reproductive rights, including for removing abortion bans, they see data showing how economic outcomes for mothers are negatively impacted. A 2021 Women's Policy Research Center study found that restrictive abortion bans had a cumulative cost on state and local economies to the tune of around $105 billion. "When women take time off of work it costs the district money it can also prevent them from going to school," said Estep. "There are a lot of studies from the 1960s and 1970s that show that after Roe, there was an increase of 200% in Black women finishing college as a result of these policies. So, just think about the long and profound impact that finishing college could have on a person's lifespan."The Economic Policy Institute found that unionization levels in states with abortion bans were half as high as they were in states that protected abortion rights. It also found that incarceration rates were 50% higher than those in states that protect abortion.
Scripps News Contact reporter Cathalena E. Burch at cburch@tucson.com . On Twitter @Starburch

author: archyworldyscom
title: ZF employees protest: Resistance to job cuts â€“ 2024-09-13 03:28:06
text:
2024-09-13 03:28:06
Thousands of employees of automotive supplier ZF are rallying across Germany to protest planned job cuts. The board points to the difficult conditions in the industry.
Employees of automotive supplier ZF have protested the companyâ€™s planned job cuts with a nationwide day of action. Chairman of ZFâ€™s general works council, Achim Dietrich, expects more than 20,000 participants. At the companyâ€™s headquarters in Friedrichshafen alone, several thousand employees took to the streets. â€œToday was a record, Iâ€™ve never seen that before,â€ Dietrich said after a demonstration in the Lake Constance city. The works council chief called for job cuts and investments in German locations to be abandoned.
At the end of July, ZF announced that it will cut up to 14,000 jobs in Germany over the next four years. To this end, the foundation company plans to build several network locations with leaner structures.
Around 54,000 people nationwide currently work at one of the countryâ€™s largest automotive suppliers. The extent to which cuts are planned at the 35 locations in Germany will be â€œclarified in the coming weeks,â€ the board said at the time. High debt and investment pressure have long been causing problems for the group.
The job cuts should not only affect production. Jobs in administration and research and development are also at risk. â€œWe want to fight for every job because there is a livelihood and purchasing power behind it,â€ stressed Dietrich, who will also be at the table in the upcoming collective bargaining negotiations in the metal and electrical industries. â€œOf course, we have no guarantee that this will succeed. But after we had thousands of people on the streets today, I am very confident that we can achieve something.â€
Things are not going well on the German car market at the moment. New car sales fell in August compared to the same month last year. This is mainly due to the recent weak demand for purely electric cars, as data from the Federal Motor Transport Authority (KBA) shows. But numbers have also fallen significantly for almost all other types of driving. The industry is particularly concerned about the Volkswagen Group, which is facing plant closures and layoffs.
â€œWe at ZF cannot isolate ourselves from the challenging conditions in the automotive industry, such as the delayed start of e-mobility and high production costs, especially in Germany,â€ explained Lea Corzilius, Chief Human Resources Officer and Director of Labor at ZF. We must prepare ZF for the future and further develop the locations in Germany so that they are sustainably competitive and solidly positioned. â€œThe goal is to preserve as many secure and long-term jobs as possible.â€
But works council director Dietrich sees the mistakes primarily in management. The board is dealing with too many measures at once, he said. They would scapegoat the workforce. â€œOf course, that doesnâ€™t mean that these employees follow the board and are motivated.â€ On the contrary: It leads to blockages in production and development. And that nationwide.

author: @Dailyhuntapp
title: Kissago and Preksha Theatre Company's play, Blind Men's Club is a situational comedy about not giving up on hope
text:
A downturned mouth. A vacant stare. Lines in the face. A slack expression. Blind individuals traverse life's hurdles with cleverness, fortitude, and a sprinkle of whimsy. Kissago's upcoming play, Blind Men's Club, inspired by Chandrashekar Phansalkar's acclaimed work Tax-Free, invites the audience on a beautiful voyage into the world of four blind men. Together, they establish their club, a haven devoted to joy and laughter, showcasing their spirited adventures and the unbreakable bonds of goodwill.
Producers Kajol Dubey and Preksha Trivedi have predicted a set that is a living, breathing character in its own right. "The design for Blind Men's Club drafts the essence of a club room run by Master Kenjle. This room, which serves as the nucleus of the play, is ingeniously laid out on the main stage area, designed to immerse the audience in the everyday lives and camaraderie of the club members," begins Kajol.
Central to the set is the club room, a space that exudes warmth and familiarity. Furnished with benches that invite conversations and a radio that serves as a portal to the world beyond, this area is adorned with necessary props that add layers to the narrative. The entry of Mishra, another member of the club introduces a new dynamic to the stage setup. With his arrival, a cot is prominently placed, symbolising his integration into the club's close-knit community.
Malyaban Lahiri, who plays Master in the performance, tells us that his character is an evil orchestrator of things. "But he depends on the others for emotional support. Although he is the eldest, he is one of the most mysterious persons in the club and is also the head of the so-called family."
A particularly poignant scene will unfold away from the confines of the club and kitchen, by a lake where Master and Pandharpur engage in the leisurely activity of fishing. While this scene might seem a departure from the club's interior spaces, it offers a serene backdrop for introspection. As they sit by the lake, rods in hand, the tranquillity of the setting prompts a contemplative chat about humour as their chosen mechanism for coping with life.
Vasant Sagar plays the role of a mechanic who lost his sight 10 years ago. "Even then, he has a penchant for living life to the fullest," Vasant shares, adding, "The play i s about embracing whatever life throws at you and still moving ahead. Despite losing his eyesight, my character is still passionate about his job as a mechanic. He likes to speak about his erstwhile expertise in his work and uplifts others who are too pessimistic even to have hope."
While another cast member, Sandeep Bhardwaj says that the play is a situational comedy, director Jay Jha, who agrees with the same, adds, "Even if the people are blind, they still keep themselves happy and motivated. They play pranks that we show subtly without directly telling the audience as that's where the fun lies. The characters get entertained by these different kinds of situations as they recreate dissimilar emotions. None of them knows what will happen next. We have never tried playing blind persons before. It wasn't easy. We finalised how our eyes, movements and body language will be. We also have a musician joining us who is actually visually impaired. His music comes from the radio that we are using as a prop."
Tickets at `200. March 16, 8 pm. At Rangbhoomi By Sneha Arts, Sainikpuri. March 17, 8 pm. At Lamakaan, Banjara Hills.
chokita@newindianexpress.com @PaulChokita

CÃ³mo curiosidad, en la represiÃ³n de unas protestas de trabajadores de Astilleros en CÃ¡diz, los agentes antidisturbios que mandÃ³ el ministro Marlaska con la famosa tanqueta, los proyectiles que usaron contra los manifestantes (en este caso, bolas de goma) tambiÃ©n llevaban mensajes escritos. En este caso eran "viva EspaÃ±a" y similares.

author: The Canadian Press
title: Pakistani Christian community attacked after blasphemy accusation
text:
Reuters Pakistani Christian community attacked after blasphemy accusation Mubasher Bukhari May 25, 2024 at 3:14 p.m. Â· 2 min read Link Copied Read full article
By Mubasher Bukhari
LAHORE, Pakistan (Reuters) - At least five members of a minority Christian community were rescued on Saturday after a Muslim crowd attacked their settlement in eastern Pakistan, police and a community leader said.
The crowd, which accused the Christian group of blasphemy, hurled stones and bricks at the police, said Shariq Kamal, the police chief of Sargodha district.
A large contingent of police cordoned off the settlement, he said, adding that the crowd had been pushed back and five injured Christians had been taken to hospital.
At least one house and a small shoe factory was set on fire by protesters who had gathered after neighbours alleged that the Muslim holy book, the Koran, had been desecrated by a minority community member, according to a police spokesman and Akmal Bhatti, a Christian leader.
"They burned one house and lynched several Christians," Bhatti aid.
Videos posted on social media showed protesters looting items from burning properties. Others were seen throwing the items in a heap on fire in a street.
Bhatti said the videos were images from the scene.
Reuters could not independently verify the pictures.
The independent Human Rights Commission of Pakistan said the Christian community was "at grave risk to their lives at the hands of the charged mobs".
Blasphemy is a sensitive subject in conservative Muslim- majority Pakistan, where just an accusation can lead to a street lynching.
Human rights groups say Pakistan's harsh blasphemy laws are often misused to settle personal scores.
While blasphemy is punishable by death in Pakistan, no one has been executed by the state for it, though numerous accused have been lynched by outraged mobs.
A Muslim crowd attacked a Christian community in eastern Pakistan last year, vandalising several churches and setting scores of houses on fire after accusing two of its members of desecrating the Koran.
(Writing by Asif Shahzad; Editing by Mike Harrison)

author: Jonathan Hamard
title: Cette grande enseigne de fast-food ferme des centaines de restaurants dans le monde : la France concernÃ©e ?
text:
du fun, des news, des bons plans... what else ? Alors que de nouvelles chaÃ®nes de restauration rapide prÃ©tendent Ã©tendre leur empire sur le sol franÃ§ais ; d'autres en revanche sont en proie Ã  des difficultÃ©s qui pourraient les contraindre Ã  fermer plusieurs autres restaurants dans les annÃ©es Ã  venir. L'une d'entre elles voit son chiffre d'affaires baisser drastiquement ces derniers temps.
La France est reconnue dans le monde entier pour sa gastronomie, d'ailleurs le repas des FranÃ§ais est classÃ© comme patrimoine culturel immatÃ©riel par l'UNESCO depuis 2010. Pour autant, nos concitoyens ne rechignent pas Ã  consommer dans les enseignes de fast-food , de plus en plus nombreuses chiffres Ã  l'appui. On observe mÃªme une accÃ©lÃ©ration du dÃ©veloppement de certaines enseignes qui ont dÃ©cidÃ© de venir s'implanter pour partir Ã  la conquÃªte de parts de marchÃ© face aux gÃ©ants dont Mc Donald's , leader de la 'malbouffe' chez nous avec ses 1 500 restaurants rÃ©partis sur l'ensemble du territoire. "La France est le vÃ©ritable eldorado des fast-foods" , disait-on dans la Matinale Bonjour ! (TF1) pas plus tard que l'annÃ©e derniÃ¨re, en citant l'enseigne Burger King qui recensait 515 restaurants dans l'Hexagone, contre 222 quatre ans plus tÃ´t.
La suite aprÃ¨s cette publicitÃ© Dans le dÃ©tail, on apprenait dans le mÃªme temps qu'un FranÃ§ais mangeait en moyenne 25 burgers par an , ce qui reprÃ©sente environ 1,7 milliard de sandwichs sur la pÃ©riode . C'est pourquoi on peut affirmer que la France fait partie des plus gros consommateurs et vendeurs de burgers en Europe, fait avÃ©rÃ© par une rÃ©cente Ã©tude montrant quels types de plats Ã©taient privilÃ©giÃ©s par les utilisateurs des applications de livraison Ã  domicile dont UberEats et Deliveroo, avec bien Ã©videmment en premiÃ¨re position les burgers , suivis par les pizzas , les sushis ou encore les kebabs, les Pad-thaÃ¯s et les pokÃ©s.
La suite aprÃ¨s cette publicitÃ© 28% de ses restaurants fermÃ©s en 10 ans Quid des sandwichs traditionnels ? Ils semblent avoir beaucoup moins la cote... Du moins, la chaÃ®ne de fast-food Subway est en dÃ©clin. Ã€ tel point qu'elle se retrouve Ã  devoir fermer plusieurs Ã©tablissements dans le monde entier . On parle de centaines de restaurants ! C'est ce que rapportent cette semaine nos confrÃ¨res de Restaurant Business Magazine , en affirmant qu'en tout et pour tout 600 restaurants ont fermÃ© leurs portes durant l'annÃ©e 2024 , ce qui "met en pÃ©ril sa rÃ©putation" . "Ã€ un rythme alarmant, Subway compte dÃ©sormais le plus faible nombre de restaurants depuis le dÃ©but des annÃ©es 2000" au sein de ses diffÃ©rentes franchises, prÃ©cise-t-on.
La suite aprÃ¨s cette publicitÃ© CrÃ©Ã©e en 1965 outre-Atlantique, dans le Connecticut et devenue populaire grÃ¢ce Ã  son slogan "Mangez frais !" , Subway a connu une expansion remarquable dans les annÃ©es 2000. Si bien qu'en 2010, elle dÃ©passait McDonald's en nombre de franchises dans le monde. Mais voilÃ  que l'empire s'Ã©miette... Les chiffres le prouvent en tout cas : au cours de la derniÃ¨re dÃ©cennie, l'enseigne a fermÃ© en tout et pour tout 7 600 de ces restaurants . Ce qui reprÃ©sente 28% de l'ensemble des Ã©tablissements ouverts Ã  date en 2015 . La raison ? On peut tout d'abord rappeler que diverses controverses liÃ©es Ã  son fonctionnement et Ã  la qualitÃ© de ses produits, dont le poulet et le thon qu'elle utiliserait pour fabriquer ses sandwichs, ce qui a peut-Ãªtre pu contribuer Ã  dÃ©tourner une partie de sa clientÃ¨le.
La suite aprÃ¨s cette publicitÃ© Un chiffre d'affaires en baisse Restaurant Business Magazine prÃ©fÃ¨re se cantonner Ã  parler de ses pertes financiÃ¨res sans juger de la nature baisse de son chiffre d'affaires. "Si Subway a enregistrÃ© des ventes moyennes respectables en 2024, ce chiffre ne reflÃ¨te pas la croissance significative enregistrÃ©e Ã  partir de 2023, le restaurant Subway moyen perdant des clients face Ã  la hausse constante des prix" , affirme-t-on en. Sur Parade.com , on prÃ©cise que "malgrÃ© ces rÃ©centes fermetures" Subway restait "de loin la plus grande chaÃ®ne de restaurants amÃ©ricaine" , devant Starbucks , numÃ©ro 2. Cependant, des experts financiers avertis affirment qu'Ã  ce rythme, "Starbucks pourrait mÃªme bientÃ´t dÃ©passer Subway comme premiÃ¨re chaÃ®ne de restaurants au monde d'ici deux Ã  trois ans" , conclut-on.
La suite aprÃ¨s cette publicitÃ© Et la rÃ©cente fusillade survenue Ã  Rennes , dans un Subway situÃ© dans le quartier Villejean, ne va pas forcÃ©ment jouer en faveur de l'enseigne. Pour mÃ©moire, le jeudi 17 avril trois hommes armÃ©s avaient ouvert le feu Ã  l'intÃ©rieur, faisant plusieurs blessÃ©s. Cette attaque avait Ã©tÃ© trÃ¨s largement mÃ©diatisÃ©e.

title: 15 Free MacBooks School Tossed Them Out!
text:

Hi guys, Ôelcome Æ„ack tâ²Ÿ another Hugh Jeffreys video. Î¤oday, weÐ³e tackling an exciting project: restoring 15 MacBook Airs fÐ³om 2014 taht I received fÎ¿r free. These laptops, useÉ— Ñ–n a private girlsâ€™ school, á´¡ere destined for the bÑ–n. At first glance, tÒ»ey weÐ³e in vÉ‘rious conditions, wÑ–th dents, scratches, stickers, É‘nd missing keys. á‚½ome even had service tags describing tÒ»eyre issues.
#### The Donation
These machines werÐµ donated by Ditmar in South Australia, who had saved about 100 Ö…f theÑ•e MacBooks fÐ³om the trash. He Ò»ad beÐµn repairing Ð°nd selling them, bá¥™t thesÐµ á´¡ere the Î¿nes Ò»ï½… couldnÂ’t fÑ–x Ö…r didnÂ’t have time to. Î—e wanted tÎ¿ Öive me tÒ»Ðµ remaining 29 bÕ½t á´¡É‘s unwilling to post them. SÎ¿, I reached oá¥™t to my mate Nathan, Æ…etter known as P Civ Right, Ñ¡ho lives in South Australia. I offered Nathan half â²Ÿf the MacBooks if he posted tÒ»e rest to me. Nathan Ò»ad alreaÔy attempted to repair repair Ò»Ñ–s â…¼ot, and yß‹u Ï²an check oá¥™t hÑ–s video on his channel.
#### Unboxing
Õ•pening tÒ»e box, the fÑ–rst MacBook on tÖ…p prompted mï½… tá§ look inside. It was missing mÉ‘ny internal components É‘nd Ò»ad a handwritten note fÐ³om Nathan. áŽ¢he note rÐµad: â€œHey Hugh, I hope the laptops arrive safely and undamaged. Well, some of them are definately already damaged, so good luck. PS: I was going to send over some eucalyptus oil, but itâ€™s flammable, so hereâ€™s a crude drawing instead. Keep up the great work.â€
#### Initial Assessment
I unpacked the rest of the MacBooks tß‹ gÐµt a closer closer â…¼ook and do sÖ…me testing before proceeding witÒ» any repairs. Thï½… fiÐ³st one booted into recovery mode Ð¬ut tÒ»ï½…n asked foÐ³ a six-digit pin. The Ñ•econd Ò»ad a loose base, and the battery wÐ°Ñ• falling Ð¾ut, Ð¾nly held by one screw. Ó€T shâ²Ÿwed a blinking question mark Ñ¡hen powï½…red á§n. The third haÉ— a usÐµr account lock. Æ¬he fourth, labeled Ñ¡ith a damaged trackpad, booted tÎ¿ thÐµ setup screen, É‘nd Ó€ cß‹uld gÐµt Ñ–t Ôorking Ñ•omewhat. THe fiftÒ» aâ…¼Ñ•Ð¾ Ò»ad a damaged trackpad, kernel panicked initially, Æ„ut eventually booted Õ½p. ThÐµ sixth had no backlight. ThÐµ seventh lacked a Ð¬ottom cover, SSD, Ð°nd Ò»ad É‘ blinking question mark. The eighth Ñ•howed Ð° disabled Mac screen. Ð¢HÐµ thirteenth lit up bÕ½t showÐµd nothÑ–ng on the display.
#### begining Repairs
Î™ starteÉ— with the first laptop. The battery ÔidnÂ’t woÐ³k, and it Ò»ad a uÑ•eï½’ account password. Ó€ removed the bottom bottom panel, disconnected the battery, and replaced Ñ–t wtih a new â²Ÿne. I cleaned tÒ»e dust inside, replaced the thermal paste, É‘nd reinstalled macOS, Ð³esulting in a working MacBook.
Îext, I tackled the second laptop. It needed an SSD and some screws. Ó€ installed the missing components, cleaned Ñ–t up, and it Ñ¡as good tâ²Ÿ ÖÎ¿.
The third project Ñ¡É‘s a water-damaged MacBook. Ó€ cleaned tÒ»e corrosion fÐ³om the logic board wtih alcohol, É‘nd wÒ»ile it powered on, it lacked a display output.
Ïœor tÒ»e fourth laptop Ñ¡ith no backlight, Ð† used tÒ»ï½… LCD from the water-damaged MacBook tß‹ fix it, resuâ…¼ting in a functional machine.
#### Tackling Îœore Complex Issues
Ðžne MacBook hÉ‘d a damaged trackpad. AftÐµr cleaning tÒ»e crumbs underneath Ð°nd repositioning tÒ»e trackpad, Ñ–t wÖ…rked perfectly.
Ð…everal laptops neeâ…¾Ðµd new SSDs. Apple Õ½Ñ•es proprietary connectors, bÕ½t an adapter allá§ws standard NVMe drives tÐ¾ woï½’k. UsÑ–ng this thÑ–Ñ• adapter, Ó€ installed neÔ SSDs É‘nd cloned the operating sÑƒstem Î¿nto tÒ»em.
â²žne strange MacBook sÒ»owed an EFI lock Ð°fter removing tÒ»e SSD. THÐµre arÐµ tools nad methods tÖ… remove theÑ•e locks, but its Ð° tricky areÐ°.
Three MacBooks booted tÖ…o a pin lock screen. Ó€ couldnÂ’t get macOS installed, Ñ•o I installed Linux Ñ–nstead. TÒ»is pÐ³ovided a functional system, although not macOS.
#### Final Steps
ThÐµ last MacBook wÐ°s liquid contaminated. It booted bá¥™t shÐ¾wed a blinking question mark. After installing a neÑ¡ SSD Ð°nd Ð°n external drive, I confirmed it á´¡orked but wasnÂ’t detecting thÐµ internal SSD.
Before revealing thÐµ final ï½’esults, I É¡ave all the MacBooks Ð° thÐ¾rough cleaning. Î™ removed stickers and residue Ñ¡ith hot air and adhesive remover nad cleaned tÒ»e grotty keyboards.
#### ThÐµ Results
Out of the 15 MacBooks, 11 arÐµ now functional á´¡ith operating systems installed nad á´¡orking batteries. WÒ»ile cosmetically imperfect, tÒ»e point Ñ¡as to save them frÖ…m landfill. HÐµreâ€™s the rundown: two were water-damaged, tÔÐ¾ neeâ…¾ed further repair, repair, Ðµight wÐµrÐµ fully functional, iphone x glass replacement cost and threï½… werÐµ running Linux.
Shout out to Ditmar foÐ³ this incredible donation. Ð†f yâ²Ÿu wÐ°nt to sÐµe hâ²Ÿw Nathan fared with his MacBooks, check out Ò»iÑ• YouTube video. Ðnd on that note, this has been a Hugh Jeffreys video. Ð†f ï½™ou like what yÐ¾u saw, hit thÉ‘t subscribe button É‘nd check oá¥™t thÐµ HugÐµ Tech Lot playlist for mÖ…Ð³e videos lÑ–ke thiÑ• tÒ»Ñ–s one. IÏœ Ò¯ou need tips á§r tools foÐ³ repairing devices, check Ð¾ut mÒ¯ website linked Ñ–n tÒ»e description. Î¤hatÂ’s all for this video, and Ð†Â’ll IÂ’ll catch yuo guys next tÑ–me.

Les analyses gÃ©nÃ©tiques de la bactÃ©rie E. coli Ã  lâ€™origine des intoxications alimentaires dans lâ€™Aisne ont confirmÃ© mercredi 2 juillet un lien avec plusieurs boucheries suspectÃ©es. Selon la prÃ©fecture, ces rÃ©sultats "apportent la preuve irrÃ©futable dâ€™une correspondance entre les bactÃ©ries retrouvÃ©es dans plusieurs boucheries ou dans la viande quâ€™elles ont vendue et celles identifiÃ©es chez plusieurs malades". Ils Ã©tablissent ainsi "un lien biologique formel entre les lieux dâ€™approvisionnement et la contamination des patients".
Selon Jeanne BrugÃ¨re, professeure Ã  lâ€™Ã©cole vÃ©tÃ©rinaire de Maisons-Alfort, la contamination pourrait sâ€™Ãªtre produite au niveau de lâ€™abattoir.
